node.title: If Australia doesn't have a radical surge in immigration, what will happen to the economy?
node.description: Here's the economic theory driving the push for Australia to have a surge in immigration.
node.content:
["I want to show you something.", "Last week I wrote about the reason why senior bureaucrats in New South Wales are pushing for a huge\u00a0surge in immigration.", "They've suggested bringing 2 million migrants into Australia over the next five years.", "They want to quickly make\u00a0up for the lost population growth we've experienced since\u00a0closing our borders last year.", "Well, this is what their argument looks like when it's presented more formally.", "Their logic is broken down into smaller steps.", "
It's a supply-side view
", "Just quickly.", "Last week I explained how, according to one school of economic thought, Australia's long-run potential growth rate is determined by three factors, which\u00a0are:", "According to the theory, if you lift the trend rate of growth of any of those three factors\u00a0you lift the potential growth rate of the economy itself.", "So, if productivity growth is low, and you can't lift\u00a0participation much\u00a0any more, you can still engineer growth by increasing the rate of growth of the\u00a0population.", "When you look at the economy that way, it's called a \"supply-side\" view of the world.", "Last month\u00a0economists from Fitch Ratings published a small paper explaining\u00a0Australia's economic predicament, and the logic of their analysis was based on a similar \"supply-side\" outlook.", "Here was their argument\u00a0step-by-step.", "
Immigration is very important
", "They said Australia\u00a0has historically relied on immigration for growth, but\u00a0since the mid-2000s\u00a0net overseas migration has picked up sharply.", "", "In fact, between 2000 and 2019, Australia experienced the fastest population gains among large developed markets.", "And for the last 10\u00a0years, population growth has been\u00a0the main source of growth for Australia's economy from a supply-side perspective.", "\"Indeed, Australia has seen a steady deterioration in underlying productivity performance, which was the main growth engine prior to the mid-2000s,\" they said.", "See the graph below.", "Note\u00a0how Australia's growth\u00a0has\u00a0become heavily reliant on growth of the working-age population (the blue lines) and the share of people in employment\u00a0(the red lines), as productivity (the green lines) has fallen away over the last decade.", "", "That accords with recent analysis from the Productivity Commission.", "According to the\u00a0PC, in\u00a0the decade before the COVID-19 outbreak, Australia experienced its slowest growth in incomes\u00a0and output (per person)\u00a0in 60\u00a0years.", "See the graph below.", "", "The Fitch economists said Australia's decision to close its international borders brought net overseas migration to a standstill in 2020 and 2021.", "It saw Australia's population increase\u00a0by only 125,000 people in 2020, around the level of natural increase, as net overseas migration turned slightly negative (-5,000). They said it's likely to be negative (-10,000) in 2021, too.", "It's had a profound impact on the labour market.", "\"There is little doubt that Australia's tight labour market and rising job vacancies in the wake of the pandemic is in large part due to the fall in net overseas migration,\" they said.", "\"Against a backdrop of supportive macro policy settings, labour demand has increased while the largest source of labour supply \u2014\u00a0net overseas migration \u2014\u00a0has dried up.\"", "", "Overall, they estimated Australia would experience a net overseas migration-induced labour supply shortfall of roughly 275,000 people across\u00a02020 and 2021.", "They assume\u00a0migration will see a gradual recovery after this year to\u00a0return to pre-pandemic levels in 2023.", "But they don't\u00a0think the shortfall in migrants in 2020 and 2021 \u2014\u00a0the people who would have come to Australia if the pandemic never happened \u2014\u00a0will be fully recovered over the next five years.", "They said that would require \"very substantial inflows\" of people\u00a0and it's not something authorities would likely be comfortable with.", "However, as we've seen, that's exactly what senior bureaucrats in New South Wales are calling for.", "That's why some bureaucrats are saying Australia should welcome 2 million migrants\u00a0over the next five years, at roughly 400,000 people a year.", "", "At any rate, what will our smaller population growth mean for economic growth?", "According to the logic of this \"supply-side\" analysis,\u00a0the negative shock to net overseas migration will hit Australia's potential growth rate.", "It\u00a0will cause GDP to be 1.9 per cent smaller by 2026 compared to its pre-pandemic path, according to Fitch's economists.", "See the graph below.", "Notice how the red line (Australia's new potential growth rate) slips below the blue line (the old potential growth rate), and how it becomes permanently lower over time?", "That's a consequence of there being fewer people in Australia than there otherwise would have been.", "", "
What will it do to wages?
", "According to Fitch's economists, it means Australia's economy will quickly run\u00a0into capacity constraints in coming years.", "They said with fewer workers in the economy, and record-high job vacancies, wage pressures were more likely to build.", "\"The stoppage of new foreign arrivals since 2020 ... clearly dried up the supply of labour,\" they said.", "\"We believe the dislocation between labour demand and supply \u2014\u00a0unwitnessed in recent history \u2014\u00a0will eventually translate into higher wage growth, probably from mid-2022 when the economy will be in full swing.\"", "They said the higher wage growth would push inflation higher, too.", "\"This is predicated in part by our expectation that underlying labour productivity growth will remain slow,\" they said.", "\"It means businesses will pass higher labour costs into output prices to preserve profit margins in an environment of strong demand, which we expect in 2022-2023.\"", "Their analysis was published in mid-October.", "A couple of weeks later, the Reserve Bank published new quarterly forecasts that showed wage growth could hit 3 per cent by the end of 2023\u00a0\u2014\u00a0it would be the fastest rate of growth in Australian wages for a decade."]
